awd_titl_txt: Dissecting how protein degradation couples the circadian clock to downstream processes
awd_abstract_narration:
For most living organisms, specific biological processes must happen at specific times of day. For example, in plants, photosynthesis, the process that converts light energy and carbon dioxide into sugar, must be timed to daylight hours. Many additional important processes are parsed out by a mechanism that controls daily timing called the circadian clock. A lot is known about genes and proteins that make up the circadian clock in plants; however how the circadian clock actually controls particular biological processes such as photosynthesis is not known. This proposal outlines experiments that will discover connections between the circadian clock and some of these timed biological processes. Understanding these connections will help us make crop plants that produce more energy and are resistant to changes in the environment, such as those caused by global climate change. 


Much is known about the transcriptional connections between the circadian clock and downstream biological processes, but far fewer non-transcriptional connections have been made. One example is the coincidence model for seasonal flowering which exemplifies a protein degradation-based mechanism for coupling the clock to seasonal flowering. In this system a circadian clock-controlled F-box protein times the degradation of a key regulator of flowering. Beyond this example, there are 32 additional circadian clock-controlled F-box proteins with little or no known biological function. To fully understand the protein degradation-based couplings between the circadian clock and downstream processes, the functions of these F-box proteins must be understood. In this proposal a strategy is defined for inverting the function of the 32 circadian clock-controlled F-box proteins to study their functions. The completion of the experiments in this proposal will provide a critical toolset and dataset to investigate protein degradation-based coupling mechanisms between the circadian clock and downstream biological processes.  In addition, the proposed research will promote training and scientific interaction at various levels of scientific discovery. 1) Undergraduates, graduate students, post-doctoral researchers, and visiting scholars will be trained in plant genetics, molecular biology, and biochemistry in the laboratory; 2) A monthly plant ?showcase? will continue to bring together the plant science faculty, students, and personnel at Yale with New Haven high school and middle school students to foster interest in plant biology and STEM education with young scientists; 3) The proposed work is intended for direct application to crop species and will be a powerful tool to introduce environmental plasticity in order to respond to global environment changes; and 4) Dissemination of the work to the general public will be achieved using social media. The lab maintains a Twitter account (@GendronLab) and the presentations of the plant showcase are published as podcasts that are freely downloadable (http://greencafe.yale.edu). This is intended to increase advocacy for science with a focus on plant science.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Many organisms have an internal circadian clock that synchronizes activities and physiology with the day night cycles of earth. In plants the circadian clock controls photosynthesis, metabolism, growth, reproduction and defense, making it critical for the survival of plants in natural environments. The plant circadian clock is composed of genes and proteins that accumulate and are degraded each day at specific times. Much research effort has been placed in understanding the timing of genes that control clock function, but much less is known about the timing of proteins involved in clock function. What is known is that maintaining the proper degradation rates of clock proteins is critical to maintaining a 24-hour clock and maintaining the connections between the clock and downstream biological processes such as growth and reproduction. A group of proteins called E3 ubiquitin ligases control the degradation rates of clock proteins, but it has traditionally been difficult to study these proteins because they are highly redundant in plants. Thus, only one small family of E3 ubiquitin ligases that control the circadian clock and flowering time has been studied. Using this single example as a biological “roadmap” we discovered 30 additional E3 ubiquitin ligases that potentially regulate the pace of the circadian clock or the connection between the circadian clock and critical downstream biological processes. Because of traditional challenges of studying redundant E3 ubiquitin ligases our laboratory had to devise a new genetic strategy. We created what we term “decoys” for each of the 30 E3 ubiquitin ligases from our preliminary screen. When expressed in plants the decoy proteins inactivate all of the endogenous E3 ubiquitin ligase proteins naturally expressed in the plant cell allowing us to bypass gene redundancy issues that have prevented progress in the field. We then determined if expressing the E3 ubiquitin ligases as decoys affect circadian clock, growth, or reproduction. We identified new regulators of leaf growth that are likely involved in sensing stress conditions, new regulators of hypocotyl elongation, and new regulators of the pacing of the circadian clock. We have performed biochemical and molecular studies to determine the degradation targets of these E3 ubiquitin ligases and also explored developmental pathways that they control using physiological assays and genetic analyses. These studies will be critically important for our understanding of how the circadian clock controls traits that are important for crop productivity in changing environments. Furthermore, clock modifications are common for domestication of plant species across latitudinal boundaries. These studies will provide new genetic engineering nodes to optimize crop productivity and allow for a larger range of growth across the globe.

 

Broader Impacts

In line with the goals that have been put forth by the NSF, the proposed research promoted training and scientific interaction at various levels of scientific discovery. 1) Undergraduates, graduate students, post-doctoral researchers, and visiting scholars were trained in plant genetics, molecular biology, and biochemistry; 2) Trainees from the PASSAGE program, intended for local students with autism or emotional disorders, gained experience in the lab in preparation for higher education or work placement; 3) Our monthly Green Café brings together plant science faculty, students, and personnel at Yale with New Haven high school and middle school students to foster interest in plant biology and STEM education with young scientists; and 4) Dissemination of the work to the general public was achieved using social media. The lab maintains Twitter accounts (@GendronLab and @14GreenCafe) and the Green Cafe presentations are freely downloadable at the Green Café website. This was intended to increase advocacy for science with a focus on plant science.
